title-group.article-title: Systematic review and meta‐analysis of vancomycin therapeutic level for treatment of vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections

article-meta.issue-title: Themed Issue: What can pharmacokinetic modelling do for you? Rational design and interpretation of clinical studies

sec.title: Aims
sec.p: Evidence on the optimal targets of vancomycin for treating other Gram‐positive infections apart from methicillin‐resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is lacking. This review aims to identify the recommended vancomycin therapeutic level for favourable clinical outcomes among patients infected with vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Analytical studies describing the vancomycin levels of vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections among adult population were searched. The primary outcome was 30‐day all‐cause mortality, and the secondary outcomes were clinical failure and nephrotoxicity. Study characteristics were extracted and pooled using random‐effects meta‐analysis. The study quality was assessed using the Joanna Briggs Institute critical appraisal tool.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total of nine retrospective cohorts studies involving 1013 patients with vancomycin‐sensitive enterococci were included. The meta‐analysis found that high area under the curve to minimum inhibitory concentration ratio (AUC/MIC) of vancomycin ≥ 389 mg*h/L significantly lowered the 30‐day mortality (odds ratio [OR], 0.44, 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.26–0.75). Analysis of the target AUC/MIC showed that high vancomycin AUC/MIC (≥ 389–400 mg*h/L) significantly reduced clinical failure rate (OR 0.59, 95% CI 0.37–0.94). The mortality and treatment failure rates did not differ significantly between those with high or low trough levels. Higher vancomycin AUC/MIC and trough levels were significantly associated with increased nephrotoxicity (OR 3.11, 95% CI 1.65–5.89; OR 2.95, 95% CI 1.60–5.44, respectively).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The use of a higher vancomycin AUC/MIC concentration can be effective to reduce 30‐day mortality and clinical failure but this needs to take into consideration the risk of nephrotoxicity. Well‐conducted prospective studies are warranted due to the scarcity of evidence.

p.mixed-citation: KatipW, LeeSWH, KasatpibalN, RayanakornA. Systematic review and meta‐analysis of vancomycin therapeutic level for treatment of vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections. Br J Clin Pharmacol. 2025;91(4):1250‐1262. doi:10.1111/bcp.1636239648680PMC11999052

sec.title: What is already known about this subject

list-item.p: Enterococci are facultative anaerobic Gram‐positive cocci that result in serious hospital‐acquired infections, and can be effectively treated with vancomycin, a glycopeptide antibiotic.
Vancomycin therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) is recommended due to its risk of nephrotoxicity.

Evidence on the optimal targets of vancomycin for treating methicillin‐resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) has been established. However, the target vancomycin concentrations for treating enterococcal infections remains controversial.

High vancomycin AUC/MIC ≥ 389 mg*h/L and ≥ 389–400 mg*h/L was significantly associated with reduced 30‐day mortality and lowered treatment failure rates among patients infected with enterococcal infections.
High vancomycin trough regimen may not be superior to low trough regimen in terms of clinical effects in treating enterococcal infections.
Both high vancomycin AUC/MIC and trough concentrations were associated with higher nephrotoxicity rate.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Enterococci are short‐ and medium‐chain Gram‐positive anaerobic cocci bacteria which pose significant challenges in healthcare settings globally. 1 , 2 These include Enterococcus faecalis and Enterococcus faecium which are common causes of hospital‐acquired infections (HAIs), particularly in the urinary tract and bloodstream, and in some cases cause serious infections resulting in infective endocarditis, bacteraemia, peritonitis and even death. 1 Due to the bacteria's survival ability in the environment and resistance to many anti‐bactericidal agents, enterococcal infection is usually difficult to treat. 1

Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that has a broad spectrum of activity against Gram‐positive bacteria such as methicillin‐resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Enterococci. It is also useful for patients with beta‐lactam‐resistant enterococcal infection and individuals who are contraindicated to beta‐lactam antibiotics due to adverse drug reactions. 3 However, due to its major adverse events such as nephrotoxicity, therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM) of vancomycin is required to reduce the risk of toxicity while maximizing therapeutic efficacy. Clinical evidence suggests that the use of vancomycin at the area under the curve to minimum inhibitory concentration ratio (AUC/MIC) of ≥ 389 mg*h/L is associated with better outcomes including reduced mortality rates, 4 but the higher vancomycin serum concentrations may potentially result in nephrotoxicity. To overcome this, vancomycin trough‐guided dosage has been suggested as a more practical option due to less need for serum collections. 5 , 6 , 7 However, recent studies have found that a high trough concentration was associated with nephrotoxicity and these levels were poorly correlated with the AUC24/MIC level. 8 , 9 Currently, the optimal vancomycin concentrations targeting a trough level of 15–20 mg/L to achieve AUC/MIC level ≥ 400 mg*h/L for methicillin‐resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection have been recommended. 5 , 10 However, there is a paucity of evidence concerning the optimal vancomycin concentration in the management of Gram‐positive infections in addition to MRSA, particularly Enterococcus spp. This systematic review and meta‐analysis was conducted in order to identify appropriate vancomycin therapeutic level for optimal clinical outcomes including 30‐day mortality, clinical failure and nephrotoxicity among patients infected with vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: This systematic review and meta‐analysis was carried out according to the study protocol registered on PROSPERO (CRD42022380008). The study was reported following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta‐analyses (PRISMA) statement. 11 , 12 The Research Ethics Committee of the Faculty of Medicine, Chiang Mai University, granted an exemption for this study protocol (Study No. PHA‐2567‐0618).

sec.title: Search strategy and study selection
sec.p: A systematic search was performed in EMBASE, PubMed, Web of Science and Scopus using Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms “(Vancomycin) AND (enteroccoci) AND (AUC* OR trough*)” in humans without time or language restriction up to 19 March 2024 (Supplementary material, Appendix 1). Articles were included if they were analytical studies (case controls, cohort studies, experimental/randomized controlled trials [RCTs]) with TDM of vancomycin therapeutic level in vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections among adult patients. We excluded qualitative studies, case series, case reports, review, systematic review and meta‐analysis studies. The references cited in the identified articles were also cross‐checked to identify potential additional articles.

sec.title: Primary and secondary outcomes
sec.p: The primary outcome of interest was 30‐day all‐cause mortality, which was defined as fatality from any cause during 30 days following enterococcal infection. Secondary outcomes were clinical failure, defined as partial or no improvement of leucocytosis, fever and local signs and symptoms of enterococcal infections after completing the treatment. Adverse event nephrotoxicity was defined by the 2009 vancomycin consensus guideline as an increase in serum creatinine (SCr) of 0.5 mg/dL or 50% higher than the baseline of two consecutive measurement occasions 5 or the more sensitive Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, and End‐stage Kidney (RIFLE) criteria 13 or the Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) criteria. 14

sec.title: Data extraction
sec.p: Studies were screened and identified for inclusion by A.R. and checked against the inclusion criteria by W.K. Eligible studies were extracted by A.R. and W.K., and data were confirmed by S.W.H.L. and N.K. Discrepancies or disagreements were resolved through discussions until consensus was reached.

sec.title: Risk of bias assessment
sec.p: The Joanna Briggs Institute (JBI)’s critical appraisal tool was applied according to the relevant study design of the included studies. 15 Three reviewers (A.R., W.K., S.W.H.L.) independently assessed the risk of bias of studies included based on the critical appraisal checklist for cohort studies by the JBI. 16 The checklist contains 11 questions in which the answer could be “yes”, “no”, “not applicable” or “unclear” to evaluate specific domains in terms of the potential risk of bias of each included study. Any controversy or discrepancies were resolved through consultation with all authors to reach a consensus. Each study's risk of bias was categorized into low risk of bias when more than 70% of “yes” scores was reached, moderate risk of bias if the study's scores of “yes” ranged from 50% to 69% and high risk of bias when the study's “yes” scores reached up to 49%. 17

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: A random effects meta‐analyses for the odds ratios (ORs) were used to assess the association between the vancomycin low and high trough level (< 15 mg/L vs. ≥ 15 mg/L) or AUC24/MIC ratio < 389 mg*h/L vs. ≥ 389 mg*h/L. The effect sizes (ES) for each study were displayed using forest plots with corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CIs) and overall estimated ES, and the I 2 statistic was used to test for levels of heterogeneity. Sources of heterogeneity, according to study‐specific characteristics (e.g., population, clinical/outcome measurement) were also explored. STATA version 16.1 (College Station, TX, USA) was used for all analyses.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: Of the 4853 records identified, 4795 articles remained after removing duplicates. Upon title and abstract screening, 4760 irrelevant studies were excluded, with 35 studies undergoing full text eligibility assessment. An additional five articles were also identified from other sources (two studies from websites, and three studies from verification of the reference lists) which underwent eligibility assessment. Of these, nine studies met the inclusion/exclusion criteria and were included in the review (Figure 1) (Figure S1.1, Supplementary Appendix 1). Details of the 27 studies excluded after being reviewed in full are presented in Table S1.1 in the Supporting Information.

caption.p: Flow diagram of search strategy and study selection.

sec.title: Study characteristics
sec.p: All included studies were retrospective cohort studies, which included 1013 patients with a mean age of 60–74 years who had enterococcal infections treated with vancomycin. Patients who had polymicrobial bacteraemia, unmeasured serum vancomycin, renal replacement therapy and isolates resistant to vancomycin were excluded. Sample size among studies ranged between 37 and 312 single or first episode of infection. Four studies were performed in Japan, 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 two studies each in Thailand 22 , 23 and South Korea 24 , 25 and one study in Singapore. 4 The included studies' characteristics are summarized in Table 1.

td.p: Patients with E. faecium, Enterococcus faecalis
Patients with E. faecium, E. faecalis
Note: 87.7% of patients had solid or hematologic malignancies

tr.td: Patients with E. faecium (73%), E. faecalis (27%) bacteraemia

td.p: Note: 63.4% of patients had a malignant tumour

fn.p: Target trough breakpoint ≥ 20 mg/L was used for nephrotoxicity; AUC, area under the concentration–time curve; C, cohort study; MIC, minimum inhibitory concentration; NA, not applicable; R, retrospective.
Luo D, Wan X, Liu J, Tong T. Optimally estimating the sample mean from the sample size, median, mid‐range, and/or mid‐quartile range. Stat Methods Med Res. 2018;27(6):1785–805.

sec.p: All included studies assessed 30‐day all‐cause mortality except Sohn et al. whose primary outcome was 28‐day all‐cause mortality. 25 The target AUC/MIC breakpoint of ≥389 mg*h/L was used in six studies 4 , 19 , 20 , 21 , 23 , 25 while two studies targeted the AUC/MIC ratio of 400 mg*h/L 22 and 414.3 mg*h/L, 18 respectively. Another study employed a target AUC/MIC breakpoint of ≥504 mg*h/L. 24 The therapeutic target of vancomycin trough level of 15 mg/L was used in all studies except in Nham et al., in which the target trough concentration of 13.94 mg/L during the first 72 h was applied. 24 Tochikura et al. targeted a trough breakpoint of 20 mg/L to investigate the association between vancomycin pharmacokinetics and nephrotoxicity. 21

Different methods were used for minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) determination. Four studies 22 , 23 , 24 , 25 used the VITEK‐2 system, of which one study also confirmed vancomycin MICs by the broth microdilution (BMD). 24 One study performed gradient diffusion E test compared with BMD and found 100% categorical agreement, 4 while four studies employed an automated microdilution method. 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 All studies reported using the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines (MIC of ≥ 32 μg/mL for vancomycin).

sec.title: Meta‐analysis
sec.p: A total of 1013 patients with enterococcal infections receiving vancomycin treatment in nine studies were included in the analyses. Meta‐analysis for the odds ratios (ORs) comparing individuals with the high and low concentration of vancomycin trough ≥ 15 mg/L vs. < 15 mg/L or AUC/MIC ratio ≥ 389 mg*h/L vs. < 389 mg*h/L was performed to assess the correlation between vancomycin concentration and the primary and secondary outcomes.

sec.title: All‐cause mortality
sec.p: Meta‐analysis examining the effects of vancomycin trough level for all‐cause mortality among 704 patients in five studies was conducted. 20 , 22 , 23 , 24 , 25 There was no statistically significant difference in all‐cause mortality between patients receiving treatment with vancomycin trough levels ≥ 15 mg/L and those treated with vancomycin trough levels < 15 mg/L (OR 1.18, 95% CI 0.42–3.34, I 2 = 73%), with no evidence of publication bias detected (Figure 2A) (Figure S2A, Supplementary Appendix 3). Removal of the studies by Nham et al. 24 and Sasano and Hanada, 20 in which 87.7% and 63.4% of patients had solid or haematologic malignancies, reduced heterogeneity and showed a trend toward lower mortality rate among individuals with high trough vancomycin regimen (OR 0.62, 95% CI 0.29–1.33, I 2 = 49%) (Figure 2B) (Figure S2B, Supplementary Appendix 3).

caption.p: (A) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for 30‐day mortality comparing high trough (≥ 15 mg/L) with low trough vancomycin regimen (< 15 mg/L). (B) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for 30‐day mortality comparing high trough (≥ 15 mg/L) with low trough vancomycin regimen (< 15 mg/L) after removing studies by Nham et al. and Sasano and Hanada. (C) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for 30‐day mortality comparing high AUC/MIC (≥ 389–414.3 mg*h/L) with low level vancomycin regimen (< 389–414.3 mg*h/L).

sec.p: Pooled analyses of 897 patients with enterococcus infection in eight studies 4 , 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 , 23 , 25 , 26 found that patients with high vancomycin AUC/MIC ratio (cut‐off 389–414.3) had significantly lower all‐cause mortality compared to those with low vancomycin AUC/MIC ratio (OR 0.38, 95% CI 0.20–0.72, I 2 = 48.8) (Figure 2C) (Figure S2C, Supplementary Appendix 3). Removal of two studies with target AUC/MIC breakpoint ≥ 400 and 414.3 mg*h/L from the analysis did not significantly alter the results (OR 0.44, 95% CI 0.26–0.75, I 2 = 0) (Figure S2D, Supplementary Appendix 3), with no evidence of publication bias detected (Egger's test, P = .361).

sec.title: Clinical failure
sec.p: Pooled analysis of the included four studies among 695 patients 21 , 22 , 23 , 24 demonstrated no significant difference regarding treatment failure rate between individuals receiving vancomycin high trough vs. low trough concentrations (OR 0.79, 95% CI 0.51–1.23, I 2 = 13.8%) (Figure 3A) (Figure S3A, Supplementary Appendix 3). Similarly, no significant difference in treatment failure rate among the high AUC/MIC group compared to the low AUC/MIC group was observed (OR 0.69, 95% CI 0.36–1.32, I 2 = 47.9%) (Figure S3C, Supplementary Appendix 3). However, the analysis showed a significant lower clinical failure rate among the high AUC/MIC group (≥ 389–400 mg*h/L) compared to the low AUC/MIC group (< 389–400 mg*h/L) (OR 0.59, 95% CI 0.37–0.94, I 2 = 4.2%) (Figure 3B) (Figure S3B, Supplementary Appendix 3) after removal of the study by Nham et al. with target AUC/MIC breakpoint ≥ 504 mg*h/L. 24

caption.p: (A) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for clinical failure comparing high trough (≥ 15 mg/L) with low trough vancomycin regimen (<15 mg/L). (B) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for clinical failure comparing high AUC/MIC (≥ 389–400 mg*h/L) with low level vancomycin regimen (< 389–400 mg*h/L) after removing study by Nham et al.

sec.title: Nephrotoxicity
sec.p: Nephrotoxicity was substantially higher in patients who achieved a high trough vancomycin level compared to patients who achieved a low trough vancomycin level (OR 3.11, 95% CI 1.65–5.89, I 2 = 32.9%) (Figure 4A) (Figure S4A, Supplementary Appendix 3). Similarly, the incidence rates of nephrotoxicity caused by vancomycin were substantially greater at high AUC/MIC level compared to low AUC/MIC level (OR 2.95, 95% CI 1.60–5.44, I 2 = 0) (Figure 4B) (Figure S4B, Supplementary Appendix 3). All included studies showed a significant higher nephrotoxicity rate among patients with high compared to low trough or AUC/MIC level except the study by Tochikura et al. in which the participants' mean estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) was 83.5 mL/min/1.73 m2.

caption.p: (A) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for nephrotoxicity comparing high trough (≥ 15 mg/L) with low trough vancomycin regimen (< 15 mg/L). (B) Odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for nephrotoxicity comparing high AUC/MIC (≥ 389 mg*h/L) with low level vancomycin regimen (< 389 mg*h/L).

sec.title: Sensitivity analyses
sec.p: Exclusion of the study by Nham et al., which recruited participants with solid or haematologic malignancies (87.7%) and the use of AUC/MIC target goal of ≥ 504 mg*h/L and trough concentration ≥ 13.94 mg/L, 24 reduced heterogeneity. Subgroup analysis to assess the potential impact of studies with high risk of bias could not be executed due to the small number of studies included.

sec.title: Risk of bias assessment
sec.p: Among nine studies included, 4 , 18 , 19 , 20 , 21 , 22 , 23 , 24 , 25 six studies were classified as low risk of bias 4 , 18 , 20 , 21 , 22 , 23 while the remaining three studies were considered to have a moderate risk of bias 19 , 24 , 25 according to the JBI Critical Appraisal Checklist for Cohort Studies (Table 2) (Table S2.1, Supplementary Appendix 2). 16 Some items that were poorly reported included the strategies for dealing with confounding factors and the lack of follow‐up information reported by these studies. Two studies also had unclear reporting regarding strategies to address the incomplete follow‐up rates (Figure S2.1, Supplementary Appendix 2). 4 , 19

caption.p: Summary of rating using JBI critical appraisal checklist.

tr.td: Were the two groups similar and recruited from the same population?
Were the exposures measured similarly to assign people to both exposed and unexposed group?
Was the exposure measured in a valid and reliable way?
Were strategies to deal with confounding factors stated?
Were the groups/participants free of the outcome at the start of the study (or at the moment of exposure)?
Were the outcomes measured in a valid and reliable way?
Was the follow‐up time reported and sufficient to be long enough for outcomes to occur?
Was follow‐up complete, and if not, were the reasons to loss to follow‐up described and explored?
Were strategies to address incomplete follow‐up utilized?

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This systematic review and meta‐analysis is the first study to our knowledge that synthesizes the available evidence regarding efficacy and safety of vancomycin therapeutic level for treatment of vancomycin‐sensitive enterococcal infections both in terms of AUC/MIC ratio and target trough concentration. Results of this study affirm the possible correlation between vancomycin AUC/MIC, nephrotoxicity events and clinical outcomes for enterococcal infections.

In this study, we noted that keeping vancomycin area under the curve to minimum inhibitory concentration (AUC/MIC) ≥ 389 mg*h/L was significantly associated with reduced 30‐day all‐cause mortality, while maintaining a higher AUC/MIC ≥ 389–400 mg*h/L was associated with significantly higher clinical success rates. However, it is critical to consider the elevated risk of nephrotoxicity associated with higher AUC/MIC ratio.

Vancomycin is well known for its potential to result in nephrotoxicity, but the extent of its contribution remains uncertain. 27 The reported incidence of nephrotoxicity varies and has been reported to be as low as 0% to 40%. 27 This can be influenced by numerous factors, including concomitant nephrotoxic drugs, classification of acute kidney injury, pre‐existing renal disorder, obesity, disease severity and vancomycin use. 22 , 27 The relationship between vancomycin exposure and acute kidney injury (AKI) has been investigated with moderate quality of evidence. A systematic review and meta‐analysis suggested association between vancomycin use with AKI with the relative risk of 2.45 (P < .001). 28 However, all included studies were at moderate to high risk of bias. Conversely, an RCT comparing standard treatment (anti‐staphylococcal penicillin or vancomycin) in combination with low‐dose gentamicin and daptomycin monotherapy for treating S. aureus bacteraemia and endocarditis demonstrated a similar rate in reducing creatinine clearance among those receiving vancomycin (10 out of 46; 22%) compared to penicillin (16 out of 63; 25%). 29

Our findings affirm the clinical use of AUC/MIC, which is a good predictor of vancomycin clinical effectiveness and safety, consistent with earlier research. 6 , 22 , 23 , 30 Our pooled analysis results showed significant lower mortality rate among patients with enterococcal infections receiving vancomycin AUC/MIC ≥ 389 mg*h/L while maintaining serum vancomycin trough concentrations ≥ 15 mg/L was not associated with this favourable clinical effect. Consistently, enterococcal infection patients with high vancomycin AUC/MIC had significantly higher clinical success rate compared to those with AUC/MIC at below 389–400 mg*h/L, whereas the incidence of clinical failure rate tended to be lower for high trough concentrations ≥ 15 mg/L, but it was not significant in our meta‐analysis. The findings from a prospective multicentre study investigating vancomycin efficacy with TDM in a Chinese population found that vancomycin trough concentration was not correlated with clinical outcomes but was associated with nephrotoxicity. 31 Consistently, another study in a paediatric population showed that trough concentrations were not reliable to estimate AUC/MIC and recommended not making vancomycin dosing adjustments based on trough concentrations only. 32 This suggests that high trough concentrations are probably not superior to low trough concentrations and monitoring trough concentrations alone may not be sufficient.

In our analysis, both high AUC/MIC ratio and high trough concentrations were associated with higher rate of nephrotoxicity except in the study by Tochikura et al. 21 The discrepancy could be attributable to the high eGFR among study participants (83.5 mL/min/1.73 m2) at baseline compared to the other studies. Significant association between vancomycin‐induced nephrotoxicity and trough concentrations has been observed in many previous studies. 22 , 23 , 33 , 34 It has been reported that a higher nephrotoxicity rate was associated with high trough regimen ≥ 15 mg/L and the association was even more pronounced when the serum trough concentrations were ≥20 mg/L. 23 , 33 , 35 Due to this strong correlation, special precaution is needed for vancomycin TDM, and vancomycin trough concentrations should be targeted below 20 mg/L in any circumstances.

Our study suggests targeting an AUC/MIC target close to either the lower or upper end of the recommended range (389–400 mg*h/L) based on patient severity, as this is crucial for maintaining efficacy while minimizing nephrotoxicity risk. Several studies have demonstrated that nephrotoxicity risk progressively increases at higher AUC values, particularly beyond 600 mg*h/L, with a substantial rise at 1300 mg*h/L. 36 , 37 , 38 In a TDM‐guided study, the incidence of AKI was significantly lower (9.1%) when the AUC target was above 400 μg*h/mL compared to a trough concentration‐guided TDM within 15–20 μg/mL (28.8%), highlighting the advantage of AUC‐guided monitoring for minimizing nephrotoxicity. 39 These findings underscore the importance of considering AUC/MIC as a continuous variable, as the risk of nephrotoxicity does not have a fixed threshold but rather escalates with increasing AUC values.

Individualized AUC/MIC targets based on patient‐specific risk factors could further improve treatment safety and efficacy. For patients at higher risk of nephrotoxicity—such as those with pre‐existing renal impairment, advanced age, prolonged treatment duration or concurrent use of nephrotoxic medications 40 —a cautious approach to AUC/MIC targeting is crucial. Research exploring variables to refine optimal AUC/MIC thresholds across different patient populations is needed.

Most of our included studies suggested a trend towards reduced all‐cause mortality among individuals treated with high vancomycin trough and AUC/MIC concentrations with the exception of two studies which showed significantly higher mortality rate at trough concentrations ≥ 15 mg/L vs. < 15 mg/L. 20 , 24 The modest performance in reducing 30‐day mortality might be explained by a high burden of patients with solid or haematologic malignancies and other comorbidities who might have insufficient immune response. Therefore, the mortality rate observed might have been attributable to other causes apart from enterococcal infections. The discrepancy of findings may be due to differences in the study populations, higher burden of E. faecium and small sample size.

Different antimicrobial susceptibility testing employed between studies might have had an impact on clinical outcomes. Most of the included studies used the Vitek‐2 and a broth microdilution (BMD) method, which are widely used systems for testing antimicrobial susceptibility. An evaluation study comparing vancomycin MICs for enterococci results obtained by Vitek‐2 and those obtained by the CLSI broth microdilution reported 100% essential and categorical agreements without any errors 41 suggesting the test to be a reliable method. E‐test was performed in one study by Jumah et al., which was also confirmed by automated BMD method with 100% categorial agreement. 4 Therefore, it is unlikely that this would have changed the conclusion of our study.

Several limitations can be noted in our study. First, all the included studies were retrospective cohort studies with limited sample size, which could have been potential for selection bias and confounding variables. Second, different methodological approaches might have had an impact on study outcomes. This includes variation of criteria used to define nephrotoxicity which might have resulted in variation of AKI incidences reported between studies. Also, different pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic analyses performed were probably responsible for the discrepancy of results and heterogeneity. It should be noted, however, that the heterogeneity in the pooled analysis was also secondary to the difference in study population, outcome definitions, enterococcal species identification, antimicrobial susceptibility testing and study setting. Third, all the studies included in the meta‐analysis were conducted in East and Southeast Asia countries. This may limit generalizability as the results may not represent other regions and their populations. Therefore, the results in our analysis should be interpreted with caution. Prospective, well‐designed randomized controlled trials and further meta‐analysis are needed to elucidate the relationship of vancomycin concentrations and clinical outcomes for treating infections caused by enterococci.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: According to the systematic review and meta‐analysis, higher vancomycin AUC/MIC concentrations ≥ 389 mg*h/L and ≥ 389–400 mg*h/L are associated with reduced 30‐day all‐cause mortality and lowered clinical failure rates, respectively. Both vancomycin AUC/MIC ≥ 389 mg*h/L and serum trough concentrations targeted ≥ 15 mg/L are associated with higher nephrotoxicity rate. Given the paucity of evidence regarding vancomycin therapeutic level for treatment of enterococcal infections, prospective or well‐design randomized controlled studies are warranted to settle the controversy.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: All authors contributed to the study elaboration and design. W.K. and A.R. conceived and designed the study. A.R. and W.K. conducted searching, screening and data extraction, which were confirmed with S.W.H.L. and N.K. A.R. and S.W.H.L. performed quality assessment and created tables and figures which were confirmed by W.K. and N.K. A.R. conducted meta‐analysis and interpreted the results with support from S.W.H.L. A.R. and W.K. drafted the manuscript, which was revised by A.R., N.K. and S.W.H.L. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST STATEMENT
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest. Also, the authors declare that the results presented in this paper have not been published previously in whole or part.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
ack.p: This research was partially supported by Chiang Mai University. The authors would like to thank Narawan Prasanlak, Titirat Buthsingkhorn and Ratirat Inpa for their help with initial searching and screening.

sec.title: DATA AVAILABILITY STATEMENT
sec.p: The study data and materials are in the custody of the corresponding author and can be made available on reasonable request.
